text:
founder of the startup I work at posted this, def thought provoking

<https://www.linkedin.com/posts/maximebeauchemin_interesting-question-thats-top-of-mind-right-activity-6808632061633560577-Zkql/>

“So. Business intelligence tools are arguably the “original” and most advanced form of no-code / low-code application. Clearly an interactive dashboard built in your favorite BI tool is a fairly complex no-code, specialized data app. Now here’s the question: why has low-code been so prevalent in data visualization historically while being not popular in other areas of software development? What is it that makes low-code more suited to dataviz?”

attachments.title: Maxime Beauchemin on LinkedIn: Interesting question that's top of mind right now, curious what people | 23 comments
attachments.text: Interesting question that's top of mind right now, curious what people may have to say here. Bear with me! So. Business intelligence tools are arguably... 23 comments on LinkedIn
attachments.fallback: Maxime Beauchemin on LinkedIn: Interesting question that's top of mind right now, curious what people | 23 comments

elements.text: founder of the startup I work at posted this, def thought provoking

“So. Business intelligence tools are arguably the “original” and most advanced form of no-code / low-code application. Clearly an interactive dashboard built in your favorite BI tool is a fairly complex no-code, specialized data app. Now here’s the question: why has low-code been so prevalent in data visualization historically while being not popular in other areas of software development? What is it that makes low-code more suited to dataviz?”

text:
because dataviz people don't identify primarily as "coders" and code as what they do so they are more open to other tools that solve their problems better.

Also it may be because the scope of dataviz is much smaller than "programming", so specialized tools can be created for the domain.

We don't seem to have well defined domains inside programming, they are all software, the only split I can thing right now is frontend/backend.

elements.text:
because dataviz people don't identify primarily as "coders" and code as what they do so they are more open to other tools that solve their problems better.

We don't seem to have well defined domains inside programming, they are all software, the only split I can thing right now is frontend/backend.

text: visual tools work well in process automation, games, interactive art and others. Maybe for the same reasons.

elements.text: visual tools work well in process automation, games, interactive art and others. Maybe for the same reasons.

text: for sure, definitely agree. One challenge tho is querying databases, that’s still a very software-engineering-y discipline, but even there you got SQL to help

elements.text: for sure, definitely agree. One challenge tho is querying databases, that’s still a very software-engineering-y discipline, but even there you got SQL to help

text: if I had to square the circle, I think fundamentally data processing & visualization is about transforming data and a lot of it is tabular (esp for end-users). So you can kinda do tables all the way down, occasionally some JSON / nested editors (e.g. for configuring charts declaratively)

elements.text: if I had to square the circle, I think fundamentally data processing & visualization is about transforming data and a lot of it is tabular (esp for end-users). So you can kinda do tables all the way down, occasionally some JSON / nested editors (e.g. for configuring charts declaratively)

text: its like a one way functional data flow. If you wanna do stateful stuff, you do it at the beginning (raw data, transform to add a 7 day rolling window or w/e) or at the end (e.g. last mile chart embellishments) :thinking_face:

elements.text: its like a one way functional data flow. If you wanna do stateful stuff, you do it at the beginning (raw data, transform to add a 7 day rolling window or w/e) or at the end (e.g. last mile chart embellishments)

text: I think its primarily due to this: there are two well baked and agreed upon DSLs that can be leveraged for this process. The first one is SQL/equivalent query languages. The second one is some formalization of the grammar of graphics. Most "apps" in this domain are a combination of the two.

elements.text: I think its primarily due to this: there are two well baked and agreed upon DSLs that can be leveraged for this process. The first one is SQL/equivalent query languages. The second one is some formalization of the grammar of graphics. Most "apps" in this domain are a combination of the two.

text: a big part of BI isn't just accessing tabular data though, it's about guiding the data access for an end user who is maybe an analyst or maybe an executive or maybe a random PM. in that sense, report builders are building interfaces, not just doing data access. they pick which filters are available, which are applied by default, and if the tool supports it which filters the end user can apply and how they can change the data they are viewing. the best analysts tell a story, and then make the re-telling of it self serve IMO

elements.text: a big part of BI isn't just accessing tabular data though, it's about guiding the data access for an end user who is maybe an analyst or maybe an executive or maybe a random PM. in that sense, report builders are building interfaces, not just doing data access. they pick which filters are available, which are applied by default, and if the tool supports it which filters the end user can apply and how they can change the data they are viewing. the best analysts tell a story, and then make the re-telling of it self serve IMO

text: i think that part is where the standard tension between less code and more code starts to come into play, where you want composition (so you can reuse different filtersets between different reports), or you want a separation between state and presentation (so you can change some global filter state in one UI panel and have it be reflected in another UI panel), or you need to do some heavier data processing client side because of the nature of the report (like an interactive sankey diagram or whatever)

elements.text: i think that part is where the standard tension between less code and more code starts to come into play, where you want composition (so you can reuse different filtersets between different reports), or you want a separation between state and presentation (so you can change some global filter state in one UI panel and have it be reflected in another UI panel), or you need to do some heavier data processing client side because of the nature of the report (like an interactive sankey diagram or whatever)

text: and in that sense, i kinda think the BI tools bump up against the same fundamental restrictions that low/no code tools seem to have which is that composition is hard and escape hatches are hard to make play nice with the rest of the off the shelf bits
